qas.question: To what is the circadian rhythm tied?
What conditions will produce a free-running rhythm in humans?
What are the environmental factors that can change the rhythm?
What do blind mole rats have in place of vision?
What cycle is seperate from the circadian rythem?
What does total light cause in humans?
What is the term for the environmental cues that dertermine daily rythems?
What kind of mammals need external stimuli to maintain their endogenous clock?

context: The rhythm is linked to the <a0_0><b4_0>light–dark cycle<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Animals, including humans, kept in <a1_0>total darkness<a1_0/> for extended periods eventually function with a <b5_0>free-running rhythm.<b5_0/> Their sleep cycle is pushed back or forward each "day", depending on whether their "day", their endogenous period, is shorter or longer than 24 hours. The environmental cues that reset the rhythms each day are called <a2_0><b6_0>zeitgebers<b6_0/><a2_0/> (from the German, "time-givers"). <b7_0>Totally blind subterranean mammals<b7_0/> (e.g., blind mole rat Spalax sp.) are able to maintain their endogenous clocks in the apparent absence of external stimuli. Although they lack image-forming eyes, their <a3_0>photoreceptors<a3_0/> (which detect light) are still functional; they do surface periodically as well.[page needed]
